21:49 • 2 months ago

BlockWallet

Meet our new hire‚Ää‚Äî‚ÄäJan Zibelnik, Product Manager

Meet our new hire‚Ää‚Äî‚ÄäJan Zibelnik, Product Manager #18‚Ää‚Äî‚ÄäThis is the sixteenth post in our ‚ÄúMeet our new hire‚Äù series, where we introduce you to the latest additions to our team here at BlockWallet. We‚Äôd like to welcome our latest team member, Jan Zibelnik! Jan is a talented Product Manager with previous experience in the wallet space. In his last position, he developed a product team from t
Meet our new hire‚Ää‚Äî‚ÄäJan Zibelnik, Product Manager

#18‚Ää‚Äî‚ÄäThis is the sixteenth post in our ‚ÄúMeet our new hire‚Äù series, where we introduce you to the latest additions to our team here at BlockWallet.

We‚Äôd like to welcome our latest team member, Jan Zibelnik! Jan is a talented Product Manager with previous experience in the wallet space. In his last position, he developed a product team from the ground up, and now, he‚Äôs bringing his advanced skillset to BlockWallet.

What‚Äôs your job position?

I‚Äôm the Product Manager here at BlockWallet. That means I‚Äôm responsible for identifying customer needs and business objectives. In addition to that, I also need to figure out what products and features will help us fulfill those needs and objectives of our users, and articulate them for everyone in the company to understand.

My day-to-day includes competitor research, user interviews, formulating requirements, and aligning business and development efforts.

How long have you worked as a product manager?

I started working in product in 2018 at my previous company, GateHub. I transitioned from wallet support into product management and we basically had to set up the new department from scratch. After we got the ball rolling, we managed to deliver some neat products to the market. This included a decentralized trading app and an on-chain crypto insurance solution, which from what I know, is the first of its kind and has not been replicated yet.

Which projects have you worked on before?

I previously worked at GateHub, which is an XRPL gateway and wallet. We offered users a custodial wallet with some unique features like web monetization and a non-custodial XRPL wallet for all kinds of on-chain interactions. In parallel, I was also a judge in the XRPL Grants program, where developers can receive grants for building solutions that leverage the XRPL blcokchain.

When did you first get involved in crypto?

I first heard about crypto in 2016. I created my first account and bought my first crypto in September or October that same year. It was a very calm time for about a year, so I had time to learn and realize what it could hold for our future. I‚Äôm really glad I‚Äôm able to say that I survived some highs and lows during this period.

In late 2017, I switched from my previous career as a football coach to a full-time job in crypto.

What made you interested in BlockWallet?

I learned of BlockWallet when I received a call from Felipe, the Cheif Vibe Officer here at BlockWallet. I was on the lookout for a new challenge after 4+ years at GateHub, and was keen to switch companies to start learning new stuff‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääjoining BlockWallet and transitioning to an EVM + self-custodial wallet was very intriguing to me. On top of that, when I learned about how BlockWallet wanted to position itself in the market, I was convinced.

I‚Äôm sure that in the long run, products that care about their users will prosper. A lot of the time it‚Äôs harder to be ethical and caring, especially if the competition is not, but my personal and professional tendency is to think about the user first, making this relationship a natural match.

Why do you think privacy matters on blockchains?

Because even if you have nothing to hide, you never know who is looking.

That‚Äôs the short answer. The long one though, is a bit more complicated.

The internet does not have a built-in monetization system. The result of this oversight at the very beginning is ads and data mining which online businesses need to do in order to stay afloat. In the years of Web2, data mining has become so sophisticated and widespread that only the most skilled users are able to remain fully anonymous. Most of us are just leaving bits and pieces of our info and behavior scattered all over the internet. The result is, that with a bit of effort, your sensitive info can be tracked and exploited, even if you take great care‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääbut who really has time to think about that?

This is why privacy is so critical to help break our digital footprint. Our phone and laptop, our browser, our wallet, our paid services‚Ä¶they should work for us, not the other way around. They should help use preserve our privacy.

Do you have any predictions on where crypto will be 5 years from now?

5 years ago, we had ICOs and CryptoKitties. We had our share of scams, but I feel it was a more innocent place back then.

In 5 years, we‚Äôll probably see an evolution of everything we know now. DAOs are probably going to become more sophisticated, trustworthy, and effective. NFTs are going to break into the mainstream, but they will evolve into more than overpriced JPEGs. Think tickets to events, proofs of ownership, proofs of participation‚Ää‚Äî‚Äästuff we already know, but better. Regulations are going to come into force and evolve too, which should make the space somewhat safer and more reliable.

We are going to have new players that will want to disrupt traditional CEXes where Celsius and FTX failed. So I expect to see new (decentralized and centralized) players in stocks, futures, derivatives, indices etc.

Finally, we can probably expect the next bull run to be fuelled by some hot new tech (gaming, metaverse, something else?), more shills, more FOMO, and more everything.

My approach: stay level-headed, and stay safe ;)

Parting thoughts

I‚Äôm thrilled to be a part of BlockWallet. I‚Äôve met the team and already settled in nicely. I love the work we are doing, and I‚Äôm loving all the feedback from the community. I‚Äôm excited about the stuff we have brewing in the background and can‚Äôt wait to share it with everyone.

About BlockWallet

Welcome to Web3‚Äôs smoothest self-custodial wallet, where you can swap and bridge crypto right on the spot. Use BlockWallet with all your favorite blockchain apps and feel what it‚Äôs like to use a product built with users in mind. Private, secure, and stupidly easy to use.

Become a part of the BlockWallet community today:

Homepage | Medium | Twitter | Telegram | Discord | GitHub | E-mail

Meet our new hire‚Ää‚Äî‚ÄäJan Zibelnik, Product Manager was originally published in BlockWallet on Medium, where people are continuing the conversation by highlighting and responding to this story.

17:38 • 2 months ago

Brave Browser

Brave Wallet adds 11 new DApps to its Wallet Partner program in December

Brave‚Äôs native crypto wallet now features integrations from Civic, DeFi Land, Degen Ape Academy, EDGE, Froggy Friends, Hubble, Kamino, and more.

Brave‚Äôs native crypto wallet now features integrations from Civic, DeFi Land, Degen Ape Academy, EDGE, Froggy Friends, Hubble, Kamino, Kwenta, Orca, Push Protocol, and Slingshot.

Since launching the Brave Wallet in 2021, we‚Äôve been hard at work collaborating with developers across the Web3 ecosystem to integrate Brave Wallet support into the most used DApps on Solana, Ethereum, and EVM-compatible networks.

We‚Äôre thrilled to end the year with 85 partners that have integrated the Brave Wallet, including 11 new ones this month, as well as hundreds more DApps and wallet development kits that are now compatible with Brave Wallet. To learn more about the program and Brave‚Äôs partners, read our past announcements: June, July, August, September, October, and November.

Here are the partners that joined in December:

Civic

Civic provides identity management tools for Web3 across chains for both consumers and DApps. For consumers, Civic.me offers Dynamic Web3 profiles where you can display NFTs, manage your identity, and use on-chain messaging. For DApps, Civic Pass is an integrated permissioning tool that gives users access to their services.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôve always seen eye-to-eye with Brave when it comes to putting the privacy of our users first. That‚Äôs why we‚Äôre delighted to offer support for Brave users on Civic.me, where they can access the most advanced, privacy-focused digital identity tools on the market,‚Äù said JP Bedoya, Chief Product Officer at Civic.

DeFi Land

DeFi Land is a free-to-play farming game that aggregates and abstracts crypto elements to make it easy to use, fun to play, and engaging to learn. The game offers players the opportunity to start playing for free, grind their way up to the ‚ÄúPlay and Earn‚Äù tier, compete with other players, and craft, trade, and dive into DeFi in a fun and exciting way.

‚ÄúWe are thrilled to have Brave Wallet integrated in DeFi Land and can‚Äôt wait to build exciting future collaborative products together,‚Äù said DFL Erwin, Team Lead at DeFi Land.

Degenerate Ape Academy

The Degenerate Ape Academy is a collection of 10,000 NFTs on the Solana blockchain. As Solana‚Äôs first large-scale, truly trustless drop, they were instrumental in proving the chain‚Äôs viability as a legitimate future home of NFTs‚Äîwith over $140 million in sales.

EDGE

EDGE‚Äôs Watch2Earn is a platform that can be added to video streaming sites and apps to increase revenue through increased ad consumption and content sharing. It is supported by the EDGE Web3 Video Network. The platform allows users to earn money by watching ads and sharing content.

Froggy Friends

Froggy Friends is a collection of 4,444 friendly frogs on the Ethereum blockchain. They are a community-driven project whose core values are kindness, fairness, and integrity.

‚ÄúWe are incredibly honored to partner with a Web3 pioneer like Brave. We look forward to welcoming the Brave community into the Froggy Friends ecosystem via our integration with Brave wallet,‚Äù said Fonzy, Co-Founder at Froggy Friends.

Hubble

Hubble Protocol provides battle-tested borrowing solutions with USDH, an overcollateralized, crypto-backed stablecoin users can mint to participate in DeFi on Solana. Users can borrow USDH and leverage their portfolio against a basket of crypto assets including bluechip tokens (SOL, ETH), liquid staking tokens (stSOL, mSOL, daoSOL), and yield-bearing tokens (cTokens, kTokens) for a one-time 0.5% fee.

‚ÄúAs a DeFi protocol focused on UX and security, Hubble is more than happy to integrate the Brave Wallet for borrowing USDH. Brave has become one of the most advanced and easy-to-use browsers for Web3, and it‚Äôs chock full of security features that protect users from malicious actors as they browse,‚Äù said Marius Ciubotariu, a core contributor at Hubble Protocol.

Kamino

Kamino Finance is on a mission to become Solana‚Äôs number one liquidity destination. The protocol offers various opportunities for earning real yield and rewards from the Solana DEX ecosystem by optimizing concentrated liquidity positions. Users deposit tokens on Kamino, and the vaults automatically set price ranges, rebalance positions, and compound fees earned from trades.

‚ÄúKamino Finance is proud to integrate Brave‚Äôs browser-based wallet on the platform. Both Kamino and Brave strive to reduce the barriers to entry for participating in Web3, and access to a user-friendly crypto wallet built into the Brave Browser is a major step towards onboarding new users to DeFi,‚Äù said Mark Hull, a core contributor at Kamino Finance.

Kwenta

Kwenta is a decentralized exchange offering up to 25x synthetic leverage on a variety of assets. By leveraging Chainlink oracles and deep liquidity from Synthetix, Kwenta offers exposure to over a dozen assets including cryptocurrencies, commodities, and forex pairs. Users who trade from a Kwenta Cross Margin wallet have access to advanced order types, deposit management, and other Kwenta-exclusive features. Traders who stake the Kwenta token are eligible to earn rewards as they trade.

‚ÄúWe believe users should have access to financial tools while retaining full control of their assets. By integrating the Brave Wallet, Kwenta can further this mission by bringing decentralized perps to millions of new users with the unrivaled privacy and security offered by Brave,‚Äù said Burt Rock, MarketingDAO PM at Kwenta.

Orca

Orca is the leading crypto marketplace on Solana. The protocol‚Äôs focus on human-centered design makes it easy for anyone to trade, earn, or build in Web3. For traders, the core concentrated liquidity AMM (CLAMM) makes it easy to buy and sell crypto at the best possible price. For market makers, advanced liquidity provision tools enable highly efficient returns on capital. And for developers, Orca‚Äôs double-audited, open-source SDK and expert developer advocates simplify the process of building in Web3. Today, Orca powers everything from market-making tools to trade aggregators to games.

‚ÄúIntegrating with Brave Wallet is a meaningful step for Orca, honoring its primary mission of creating financial opportunity through equitable access for anyone. Brave‚Äôs global presence and focus on ease-of-use makes it a mission-aligned partner for Orca, and we are excited to provide Brave wallet users with access to easily trade or earn on the most capital efficient crypto marketplace on Solana, " said KZ, Head of Growth at Orca

Push Protocol

Push Protocol is the communication protocol of web3. Push enables cross-chain notifications and messaging for DApps, wallets, and services tied to wallet addresses in an open, gasless, and platform-agnostic fashion. The open communication layer allows any crypto wallet / frontend to tap into the network and get the communication across. Since its launch Push has powered over 45 Million notifications to 60k+ subscribers, across 100+ integrations and is currently live on Ethereum and Polygon.

‚ÄúOne of the most important tenets of the Web3 space is privacy. Brave has been absolutely leading the way when it comes to shipping one of the most advanced wallets and browsers that respect users‚Äô privacy. Now Brave Wallet‚Äôs integration with Push brings decentralized communications to the Brave ecosystem and serves millions of users and builders is a clear sign that privacy and decentralization are here to stay,‚Äù said Harsh Rajat, Founder at Push Protocol.

Slingshot

Slingshot is a DeFi application and wallet that lets you buy, sell, and swap over 40,000 cryptocurrencies at the best prices with 0% swap fees. Users can access real-time charts and market data for each token, set up custom price alerts, and connect with traders all over the world in the global chat. Slingshot is currently available on the Polygon, Arbitrum, Optimism, Binance, and Osmosis networks.

‚ÄúAs a web3 wallet and application, we at Slingshot are committed to ensuring the protection of users‚Äô privacy and security, especially when it comes to swapping crypto and engaging in the DeFi ecosystem. We are excited to integrate with the Brave Wallet, to further the mission of decentralization, while empowering users to take an active role in the progression of web3,‚Äù said Chelsea Spinos, Head of Marketing 

About Brave Wallet

Brave Wallet enables Brave users to store, manage, grow, and swap their crypto portfolio across multiple blockchains from a single wallet. Unlike most crypto wallets, Brave Wallet is browser-native, meaning it doesn‚Äôt require any additional downloads or extensions, helping reduce security risks and reliance on extra CPU and memory. Users can transact with thousands of crypto assets with superior safety and performance, as well as connect with other wallets and Web3 DApps. If you‚Äôre a developer interested in integrating Brave Wallet into your DApp, take a look at our developer documentation.

If you‚Äôre curious about Web3, check out our Web3 Information Hub, which features simple guides and overviews to answer all your questions.

Want a faster, more secure, and private browser? Download Brave today and take back control of your online footprint one blocked tracker at a time.

00:00 • 2 months ago

Wednesday, 21. December 2022

Epicenter Podcast

Ted Blackman & Gary Lieberman: Urbit - Decentralized Computing Platforms

When discussing the widespread adoption of true, peer-to-peer decentralization, one could easily identify various social and political obstacles. However, there is also an often overlooked technological impairment as the underlying architecture of computer networks was not designed to achieve global-scale decentralization. Ideally a complete restructuring would be necessary, from applications and

When discussing the widespread adoption of true, peer-to-peer decentralization, one could easily identify various social and political obstacles. However, there is also an often overlooked technological impairment as the underlying architecture of computer networks was not designed to achieve global-scale decentralization. Ideally a complete restructuring would be necessary, from applications and programming language, to as profound as rewriting operating system kernels. This is what Urbit is trying to achieve; a decentralized network where users have full control over their computer, running a unified operating system, where applications function seamlessly, without centralized chokepoints.

We were joined by Ted Blackman, CTO of Urbit Foundation, and Gary Lieberman, the Chorus One Team Lead for Urbit, to discuss how Urbit reshapes the way we interact with computers, its current development stage, and what challenges it has to overcome.

Topics covered in this episode:
- Ted's background
- What Urbit is building
- The disruptive potential of Urbit
- Gary's motivation behind joining Urbit
- Urbit's impact on user experience
- Current development stage and potential limitations
- General timeframe for Urbit adoption
- Other use cases for Urbit
- Implications Urbit might have for crypto (synergies)
- Privacy vs. Accountability

Episode links:
- Urbit: https://bit.ly/3A9COrX
- Urbit Foundation: https://bit.ly/3G8KZXR
- Ted Blackman: https://bit.ly/3Wuqyde
- Gary Lieberman: https://bit.ly/3YJcRt6

Sponsors:
- Tally Ho: Tally Ho is a new wallet for Web3 and DeFi that sees the wallet as a public good. Think of it like a community-owned alternative to MetaMask. - https://epicenter.rocks/tallycash

This episode is hosted by Brian Fabian Crain. Show notes and listening options: https://epicenter.tv/475

23:00 • 2 months ago

Horizen - Blog

Why Blockchain Users Are Setting Up Horizen Nodes

Similar to how Web 2.0 relies on data centers to provide the backbone for applications, blockchain technology needs nodes to keep the network humming along. Nodes verify transactions and secure the network, making them a critical part of any blockchain infrastructure. Horizen is a public blockchain with more nodes than any other blockchain. In this [‚Ä¶] The post Why Blockchain Users Are Settin

Similar to how Web 2.0 relies on data centers to provide the backbone for applications, blockchain technology needs nodes to keep the network humming along. Nodes verify transactions and secure the network, making them a critical part of any blockchain infrastructure.

Horizen is a public blockchain with more nodes than any other blockchain. In this article, we‚Äôll examine why blockchain users are setting up Horizen nodes.

Why Should You Set Up A Node?

Setting up a blockchain node is easier than ever, and there are also good reasons to do so. Let‚Äôs discuss some of the benefits of running a Horizen node.

Contributing to integrity and decentralization of a blockchain network

A nexus of nodes is essentially the infrastructure of a decentralized blockchain network. The node network plays an important role in defending the blockchain from unwanted changes. This can be especially important during times of hard fork contention. As a node operator, you have a say in how the network progresses, such as authenticating transactions and executing decision-making protocols.

Making the network more scalable and faster

Another key benefit of running a node is that it helps to propagate transactions throughout the network. By running a node, you‚Äôre helping to ensure that transactions are processed as quickly as possible.

Getting rewarded by contributing to the network

Beyond contributing to the security and resilience of a blockchain network, running a cryptocurrency node also comes with the potential to generate passive income.

Staking Rewards is a website that provides real-time information on the rewards being generated by nodes on various blockchains. For example, at the time of writing, a ZEN Securenode has a 7.77% annualized reward rate (APR), while Ethereum 2.0 has an APR of 4.8%.

The amount of reward that a node earns can vary depending on network conditions and other factors. For example, Foundry Staking recently announced the launch of its institutional-grade staking service. Through the Foundry Staking portal, institutions can stake a variety of different cryptocurrencies and receive rewards in near-real-time, including from ZEN.

How to Set Up A Horizen Node

It‚Äôs very easy to set up a Horizen node. For hassle free hosting option, we recommend checking out some of our node hosting guide to get started.  You will not need any developer skills to run nodes through hosting services. 

If you would like to self host Horizen Nodes, check out the Secure and Super Node instructions. Self-hosting your own node allows you to keep control of your transactions and maintain your privacy. 

Running a node is an important way to contribute to the health and security of a blockchain network. It‚Äôs also a great way to generate passive income. If you‚Äôre looking for an easy way to get started, we recommend checking out Horizen node hosting guide.

The post Why Blockchain Users Are Setting Up Horizen Nodes appeared first on Horizen Blog.

Nym - Medium

Nym partners with Bity

Partnership enables easier access to NYM tokens to use and operate the Nym mixnet As part of the Nym roadmap targeting a best-in-class network level privacy service, Nym has partnered with the Swiss brokerage Bity SA (Bity) to make it easier to access native NYM tokens and participate in operating the Nym privacy network. NYM tokens are the utility token of the Nym mixnet. The Nym mixnet is

Partnership enables easier access to NYM tokens to use and operate the Nym mixnet

As part of the Nym roadmap targeting a best-in-class network level privacy service, Nym has partnered with the Swiss brokerage Bity SA (Bity) to make it easier to access native NYM tokens and participate in operating the Nym privacy network. NYM tokens are the utility token of the Nym mixnet. The Nym mixnet is a powerful overlay network that protects not just your IP address, but also your patterns of communication and metadata.

Native NYM tokens allow people to take part in running the mixnet by ‚Äúbonding‚Äù a node. For those regular folks who do not want to run a mixnode, you can still contribute to ensuring strong privacy protections by staking NYM tokens on well performing mixnodes. This ensures the quality of the network and allows you to earn rewards for doing so!

This important building block of a partnership and integration with a payment gateway with Bity is will increase convenience for the Nym community, with steady usage already seen since the latest release.

How does it work?

If you already have the latest version of the Nym wallet, you will have noticed the new ‚ÄúBuy‚Äù button. The service is provided by Bity enabling people to buy tokens using BTC. There is a purchase limit of 1000 Swiss Francs per day.

The ‚ÄúBuy NYM‚Äô‚Äô button will take you to Bity‚Äôs website where you need to agree to the terms of service (please note this feature is not available to the users in the United States). Bity will then give you a message that you need to copy and sign in your Nym wallet interface, confirming that you submitted the correct wallet address. You then send Bity the BTC and they will send you your NYM tokens directly to your wallet so you can start bonding and delegating stake and contributing to the global mixnet!

‚ÄúProtecting user privacy has always been part of Bity‚Äôs DNA. That is why I‚Äôm excited to announce our partnership with Nym. By allowing our clients to buy NYM tokens, we want to help build a better world, one that is fair and accessible to everyone while respecting their privacy rights.‚Äù Yves Honor√©, CEO Bity.

Download Nym wallet

Try the Nym mixnet:

NymConnect Chat app demo Pastenym

Node set-up help chat

Discord community

08:01 • 2 months ago

Brave Browser

FrodoPIR: a new privacy-preserving approach for retrieving data

Introducing FrodoPIR, a Private Information Retrieval scheme for a variety of use-cases, such as Safe Browsing, checking certificate revocation, passwords over breached databases, streaming, and more.

Authors: Sof√≠a Celi, cryptography researcher at Brave; Alex Davidson, former cryptography researcher at Brave; and Gon√ßalo Pestana, former cryptography researcher at Brave.

One of the interesting problems in computer science with regard to security and privacy is how to retrieve items from a database, without revealing anything about the query to the untrusted server(s) where this database lives. Today, we‚Äôre going to be talking about some very recent scientific work we have done at Brave to make this a genuine possibility for a variety of applications.

The TL;DR is that we have built a new Private Information Retrieval (PIR) scheme called FrodoPIR, that we hope will make PIR easier and cheaper to deploy for a variety of use-cases and applications, such as Safe Browsing, checking passwords over breached databases, certificate revocation checks, streaming, and more. We have an open-source implementation that you can use now, as well as a paper that explains the scheme. The paper has been accepted into the first issue of PoPETS 2023!  We‚Äôre calling the scheme FrodoPIR because the client can perform hidden queries to the server, just as Frodo remained hidden from Sauron.

Private Database Access Overview

Why is the issue of privacy important when retrieving items from a database? Let‚Äôs say, for example, that you want to use your favorite streaming platform to watch videos of dogs. But, actually, you‚Äôre a little bit embarrassed of revealing ‚Äî to the platform ‚Äî how many dog videos you watch (you shouldn‚Äôt be, but that‚Äôs the world we live in). Moreover, you would love to avoid anyone from being able to exploit that data so they can show you invasive targeted advertising campaigns, for example. What would be great is if you could receive this content, without the (untrusted) provider being able to tell what it is you are streaming.

Private Information Retrieval (PIR) schemes are a set of cryptographic protocols that have been proposed as a solution to this exact problem. As with most cryptography, the first schemes arrived in the 1990‚Äôs, but it hasn‚Äôt been until the last six or seven years that candidate schemes have been designed that may approach having high enough performance to work in modern-day use-cases. However, the landscape remains quite complicated: many schemes are tailored to very specific use-cases to achieve low bandwidth or server runtimes, or they may require complex server-side deployments (e.g. using at least two non-colluding servers) to fulfill PIR queries.

With this in mind, we created FrodoPIR! This new PIR scheme we are announcing is intensely configurable, efficient across a wide swath of applications, easy to understand and implement, requires only a single untrusted server to deploy, and comes with concrete privacy and security guarantees against both classical and quantum adversaries (because we use lattices, as we will see).

PIR: The General Idea

Broadly speaking, the way that most single-server PIR schemes work is by using a cryptographic tool known as additively homomorphic encryption (AHE). Such encryption schemes allow someone with two ciphertexts that encrypt X and Y to compute a ciphertext that encrypts X+Y, without knowledge of the secret key. Such schemes have been around since RSA, but one commonly-used example is the Paillier encryption scheme.

Figure 1: an AHE system

But how do we build a PIR protocol from such a thing? As seen in Figure 1, the answer is remarkably simple:

The server organizes its database into a set of M rows, each containing a single element. In other words, the database is now a vector. Any client that wants to learn the ith element, encrypts M ciphertexts, where the ith ciphertext encrypts 1, and the rest of them encrypt 0. The client sends their ciphertexts to the server; due to the nature of the encryption, the server cannot tell what is encrypted. The server performs a scalar multiplication of each entry db_entry_1,‚Ä¶,db_entry_M of its database vector with the corresponding ciphertext in each, adds them all together into a single ciphertext and returns this back to the client. Note that scalar multiplications are possible by adding each ciphertext to itself according to the size of the scalar. Now, after the client decrypts each ciphertext, it will simply learn db_entry_i, since: 0db_entry_1,‚Ä¶,1db_entry_i,‚Ä¶,0*db_entry_M = db_entry_i.

Essentially, over the past number of years, it has been shown that constructing PIR can be done quite efficiently using this simple method (and some optimizations). This is achieved by using  AHE schemes based on cryptographic lattices, in particular based on fully homomorphic encryption (FHE) schemes, with security derived from the ring learning with errors (RLWE) assumption.

We‚Äôll talk about these a bit more shortly. Some things to note before we do:

It‚Äôs possible to construct PIR with multiple servers with higher efficiency, but under the assumption that the servers do not collude. Such assumptions are known to be quite strong in real-world settings, and it is preferred to avoid them, if possible. The server are assumed to be honest-but-curious, i.e. they execute the protocol honestly, but attempt to learn more from the client query alone. A malicious server can obviously choose to not run the PIR protocol properly, and clients will get bad answers. The server database is assumed to be public. If the database should be treated as sensitive (i.e. clients should not be able to learn anything other than their query), then PIR is not really the correct tool to use (though, there are some symmetric PIR constructions that give insight into this). Limitations to existing approaches

At Brave, we became interested in using PIR for having clients retrieve certain things from Brave, without the server knowing. Unfortunately, despite experimenting with various existing systems, we were never able to build something that didn‚Äôt involve huge costs, or large amounts of implementation complexity. This led us to start thinking about how we could try and build a PIR scheme that fit these requirements a little better and to create a new approach: FrodoPIR. Let‚Äôs see now what are the limitations of existing approaches.

A common issue even with fairly recent PIR schemes is that they are expensive in terms of either bandwidth, or in the amount of time taken to process each client query. In order to drive down the costs, FHE-based PIR schemes can move large proportions of the expensive online computation and communication (which is, for example, the sending of the query) to an offline phase (a ‚Äúpreparation‚Äù phase that can be later reused to make online queries). These kinds of schemes are called offline-online or stateful, as opposed to online-only or stateless.

However, a key difficulty that has gone unsolved is that either the computation or the communication costs induced during the offline phase scale linearly in the number of clients that will make queries, or the client has to download the entire server database (which defeats the purpose). This means that the offline phase has to be performed between each client and the server, which translates, in principle, to a lot of expensive computation that the server has to do. If you‚Äôre using commercial hardware to run your server, these costs are likely to run up huge financial costs.

Announcing FrodoPIR!

Just as the state of Sauron (its ring) moved to Frodo, we can move the mu and A to the client. The client then can then perform hidden queries to the server, just as Frodo remains hidden from Sauron.

We are excited to present FrodoPIR, a stateful PIR scheme that is built directly upon the learning with errors (LWE) problem. We get rid of the ring lattice structures (as Frodo needs to do: a reference first made in the naming of the FrodoKEM proposal, and that we now borrow ourselves) to bring a flexible and practically efficient PIR scheme for a variety of use-cases. The core of the FrodoPIR scheme is an offline phase that requires no client-dependent computation, and incurs only a relatively small download compared to the database size (e.g. 170x smaller). This makes it suitable for many large, real-world deployments, where lowering financial costs for server-side operators is of paramount importance. FrodoPIR is also significantly simpler than previous schemes, making no use of FHE techniques and requiring only modular arithmetic. Read the whole paper describing it here. 

FrodoPIR is a scheme that relies on the decisional LWE problem: each client query is a noisy vector that appears uniformly random to the server. As stated, it has both offline and online phases:

Figure 2: Diagram of the flow of FrodoPIR

In the offline phase, the server interprets the database as a matrix, applies a compression function to said matrix and makes the results available as global public parameters (mu and M). This compression function shrinks the size of the database. In the offline phase, the client downloads the public parameters (mu and M), and computes ‚Äòc‚Äô sets of preprocessed query parameters. In the online phase, the client uses a single set of preprocessed query parameters to produce an ‚Äúencrypted‚Äù query vector, which is sent to the server. The server responds to the query by multiplying the vector with its database matrix. The client returns the result by ‚Äúdecrypting‚Äù the response using its preprocessed query parameters.

What this means is that in the offline phase, the server and client prepare anything that can be previously prepared for online queries; and, in the online phase, the client sends encrypted queries to the server. The latter returns a positive or negative value depending if the query is found in the database or not. The server never learns which value you are querying for, and yet it returns the correct answer (if it was included in the database or not).

FrodoPIR is a powerful primitive as it makes PIR schemes practical for real-world usage where not only communicational and computational costs are important but also financial ones. PIRs, in general, are powerful: they can be applied to Safe Browsing, checking passwords over breached databases (or any type of credentials), Certificate Transparency (CT) checks, certificate revocation checks, or for streaming. Having a cheap and efficient scheme will help improve the privacy of the whole Internet not only for big actors, but also for anyone providing such service.

It is worth noting that there are other PIR schemes beyond FrodoPIR, but the latter outperforms them all, as seen in Figure 3 below. The figure shows a comparison of per-client computational, communication, and financial costs for the server when running FrodoPIR, Stateful OnionPIR (SOnionPIR), and PSIR, assuming that each client makes c = 500 queries.

Figure 3: Comparison of FrodoPIR with other PIR schemes

So, what is next, and how can Brave users expect to see FrodoPIR implemented? At Brave, we care about deploying privacy-preserving schemes that make the Internet private and safe. One of our next efforts is to have a credential checker: any credential entered through the Brave browser (like, for example, passwords) can be checked against known breached databases. This can provide a safe mechanism to signal users to, for example, change their passwords. But such checking (the queries launched against the breached database) should be private. And, on this, FrodoPIR shines as a mechanism to provide privacy in a financially cheap and efficient fast way.

To read more about our FrodoPIR scheme, you can find details here. The paper has been accepted to the Proceedings on Privacy Enhancing Technologies (PETS), Vol. 2023, Issue 1, and will also appear here.

00:00 • 2 months ago

Tuesday, 20. December 2022

Nym - Medium

Nym Shipyard Developer Grantees

Advancing more projects build for privacy, for a better society At Nym, it is important that more people can build for privacy in order to accelerate complete privacy protection on the new internet and the network layer is one of the hardest to protect. With surveillance now powered by Machine Learning algorithms, privacy protections need to keep pace! This means protecting not just content

Advancing more projects build for privacy, for a better society

At Nym, it is important that more people can build for privacy in order to accelerate complete privacy protection on the new internet and the network layer is one of the hardest to protect. With surveillance now powered by Machine Learning algorithms, privacy protections need to keep pace! This means protecting not just content and IP addresses but also the patterns of communications and the metadata.

Nym allows applications to easily integrate a mixnet, offering some of the strongest privacy protections to their end users. The aim is to ensure that our digital lives are safer and we can thrive in a free and surveillance-free society. And the developer grants are here to support you doing so!

The Shipyard Developer Grant scheme

As such, we recently launched the next tranche of Shipyard grants, targeted at developers. With two open calls, Vinge Grant and Brier Grant, the Developer Grant scheme is a great opportunity for us to support developers across a variety of projects.

Benefits of the scheme

The scheme will provide the winners with financial, dev, marketing and project support, to maximise their chances of a successful project. The grants scheme is designed so that projects can grow and apply for larger and larger pots and potentially graduate to the Nym Innovation fund if they wish to pursue investment opportunities.

Congratulations to the grantees

We are therefore pleased to announce the winners of the first Developer Grant scheme:

No Trust Verify DarkFi Squad NymHub dial0ut Meridien Project

Winners were selected based on quality of ideas and code. Some of the projects are also known to our Nym community. No Trust Verify is known a Nym mixnode and creator of pastenym, DarkFi is known amongst our community as the ultimate lunarpunk privacy crew and working on an interesting mixture of p2p tech and zkp, while dial0out was a former Nym core team member doing developer relations.

What can we look forward to from the grantees

We are confident that the projects that are supported by the grant will play a strong role in our push for privacy as default.

From anonymity enhancement in network p2p protocols and text and file sharing in a privacy-preserving way to a secure, private IoT hub providers and an accessible interface for interacting with Nym, our community can expect to see the exciting work to be available by the first half of next year.

Next open calls

Going into 2023, there will be regular open calls for the Developer Grants scheme for both smaller and larger grants.

If you are interested in applying for the next round, do check out the work of this round‚Äôs grantees to get inspired. We have also released tools like the Nym SDK which will continue to be fleshed out with new features such as zk-nyms (fka Coconut credentials). This means that devs will have more chances to use the SDK to integrate apps with the mixnet.

Keep an eye out on our socials to find out when the next round is opened.
